dictionary.definition: to work very hard.  She has an important deadline coming up, so she’s been working like a beaver. You need a vacation. You work like a slave in that kitchen.  I’m too old to work like a horse. I’d prefer to relax more.
Inf. Fig. to work very hard. (Use caution with butt.) _I worked my tail off to get done on time. You spend half your life working your butt off— and for what?
Inf. Fig. to work very hard. (Use caution with butt.) _I worked my tail off to get done on time. You spend half your life working your butt off— and for what?
Inf. Fig. to work very hard. (Use caution with butt.) _I worked my tail off to get done on time. You spend half your life working your butt off— and for what?
Inf. Fig. to work very hard. (Use caution with butt.) _I worked my tail off to get done on time. You spend half your life working your butt off— and for what?
to get rid of body fat by doing strenuous work.  I was able to work a lot of weight off by jogging.  I need to work off some fat.
to get rid of body fat by doing strenuous work.  I was able to work a lot of weight off by jogging.  I need to work off some fat.

dictionary.phrase: work someone or something into something
dictionary.definition: 1. to manage to fit someone or something into something physically.  The magician worked the lady into the tiny cabinet from which she was to disappear.  The magician opened the little box and worked in the lady and two small dogs. 2. to fit someone or something into a sequence or series. I don’t have an appointment open this afternoon, but I’ll see if I can work you into the sequence.  I can’t work in all of you.

1. to manage to fit someone or something into something physically.  The magician worked the lady into the tiny cabinet from which she was to disappear.  The magician opened the little box and worked in the lady and two small dogs. 2. to fit someone or something into a sequence or series. I don’t have an appointment open this afternoon, but I’ll see if I can work you into the sequence.  I can’t work in all of you.
to press, mix, or force a substance into something.  You should work the butter into the dough carefully.  Work in the butter carefully.
to press, mix, or force a substance into something.  You should work the butter into the dough carefully.  Work in the butter carefully.
to manipulate something to get it out of something. You have to work the bubbles out of the paint before you use it.  You have to stir the batter to work out the lumps.
to manipulate something to get it out of something. You have to work the bubbles out of the paint before you use it.  You have to stir the batter to work out the lumps.
excited and agitated about something. (*Typically: be ~; get ~; get oneself ~.) _Tom is all worked up over the tax increase.  Don’t get so worked up about something that you can’t do anything about.
excited and agitated about something. (*Typically: be ~; get ~; get oneself ~.) _Tom is all worked up over the tax increase.  Don’t get so worked up about something that you can’t do anything about.

dictionary.phrase: would not be seen dead (doing something)
dictionary.definition: would not do something under any circumstances. I wouldn’t be seen dead going out with Bruno! _Martha would not be caught dead going into a place like that.

dictionary.phrase: would not be caught dead (doing something)
dictionary.definition: would not do something under any circumstances. I wouldn’t be seen dead going out with Bruno! _Martha would not be caught dead going into a place like that.

dictionary.phrase: wrench something off (of) someone or something
dictionary.definition: to yank or twist something off someone or something. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _ He wrenched the shoes off the sleeping man and ran away.  He wrenched off the catsup bottle cap.
to yank or twist something off someone or something. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _ He wrenched the shoes off the sleeping man and ran away.  He wrenched off the catsup bottle cap.
to struggle to get something off something. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _Somehow he wrested the hubcap off the wheel.  He wrested off the hubcap.
to struggle to get something off something. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _Somehow he wrested the hubcap off the wheel.  He wrested off the hubcap.
to remove liquid from something by squeezing or twisting.  She wrung the water from the cloth and wiped up the rest of the spill.  Alice wrung the water out of the washcloth.
to remove liquid from something by squeezing or twisting.  She wrung the water from the cloth and wiped up the rest of the spill.  Alice wrung the water out of the washcloth.

1. to write information into something. I wrote her telephone number into my notebook.  I wrote in her number.  I took out my notebook and wrote it in. 2. to include a specific statement or provision in a document, such as a contract or agreement.  I want you to write a stronger security clause into my contract. I will write in a stronger clause.

1. to write information into something. I wrote her telephone number into my notebook.  I wrote in her number.  I took out my notebook and wrote it in. 2. to include a specific statement or provision in a document, such as a contract or agreement.  I want you to write a stronger security clause into my contract. I will write in a stronger clause.

dictionary.phrase: yank someone or something into something
dictionary.definition: to jerk or pull someone or something into something. Mary yanked Sally into the car and sped off.  She yanked in the anchor rope and we rowed away.
to jerk or pull someone or something into something. Mary yanked Sally into the car and sped off.  She yanked in the anchor rope and we rowed away.

dictionary.phrase: yank someone or something off (of) something
dictionary.definition: to jerk someone or something off something. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _She yanked the coffeepot off the counter and ran upstairs.  She yanked off the box lid.
to jerk someone or something off something. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _She yanked the coffeepot off the counter and ran upstairs.  She yanked off the box lid.

dictionary.phrase: yank someone or something out of something
dictionary.definition: to pull or jerk someone or something out of something.  Sam yanked the turnips out of the ground one by one.  He yanked out the best of the young carrots from the rich soil.
to pull or jerk someone or something out of something.  Sam yanked the turnips out of the ground one by one.  He yanked out the best of the young carrots from the rich soil.

1. Fig. to yell loud and long.  I was yelling my head off at the football game.  Stop yelling your guts out and listen to me. 2. Fig. to complain bitterly and loudly. Some lady is yelling her head off about shoddy workmanship out in the lobby.  I yell my guts out about bad service when I get bad service!

1. Fig. to yell loud and long.  I was yelling my head off at the football game.  Stop yelling your guts out and listen to me. 2. Fig. to complain bitterly and loudly. Some lady is yelling her head off about shoddy workmanship out in the lobby.  I yell my guts out about bad service when I get bad service!

Inf. a phrase that responds to a threat by implying that the threat is a weak one.  Bill: I’m going to punch you in the nose! Bob: Yeah? You and who else? _ Tom: Our team is going to slaughter your team. Bill: You and what army? _Bill: If you don’t stop doing that, I’m going to hit you. Tom: You and who else?

Inf. a phrase that responds to a threat by implying that the threat is a weak one.  Bill: I’m going to punch you in the nose! Bob: Yeah? You and who else? _ Tom: Our team is going to slaughter your team. Bill: You and what army? _Bill: If you don’t stop doing that, I’m going to hit you. Tom: You and who else?
a polite response to Thank you.  “Thank you for helping me.” “You’re welcome.” _“Thank you very much!” “You are welcome!”
a polite response to Thank you.  “Thank you for helping me.” “You’re welcome.” _“Thank you very much!” “You are welcome!”

Inf. Fig. You can be absolutely certain of something! _ Mary: Will I need a coat today? Bill: You bet your sweet life! It’s colder than an iceberg out there.  Bill: Will you be at the game Saturday? Tom: You bet your boots!

Inf. Fig. You can be absolutely certain of something! _ Mary: Will I need a coat today? Bill: You bet your sweet life! It’s colder than an iceberg out there.  Bill: Will you be at the game Saturday? Tom: You bet your boots!

Inf. Fig. You can be absolutely certain of something! _ Mary: Will I need a coat today? Bill: You bet your sweet life! It’s colder than an iceberg out there.  Bill: Will you be at the game Saturday? Tom: You bet your boots!

Inf. Fig. You can be absolutely certain of something! _ Mary: Will I need a coat today? Bill: You bet your sweet life! It’s colder than an iceberg out there.  Bill: Will you be at the game Saturday? Tom: You bet your boots!
Inf. That is true.; You are correct. (The word that is emphasized.) _ Mary: It sure is hot today. Jane: You can say that again! _ Bill: This cake is yummy! Bob: You said it!
Inf. That is true.; You are correct. (The word that is emphasized.) _ Mary: It sure is hot today. Jane: You can say that again! _ Bill: This cake is yummy! Bob: You said it!

dictionary.phrase: You cannot get blood from a stone.
dictionary.definition: Prov. You cannot get help from an uncharitable person or money from someone who has none. Jerry and James spent two hours trying to convince the old miser to contribute to the children’s hospital; finally, James turned to Jerry and said in disgust, “This is hopeless. We can’t get blood from a stone.” _ The government can’t increase taxes any further—nobody has the money! You can’t get blood from a turnip.

dictionary.phrase: You cannot get blood from a turnip.
dictionary.definition: Prov. You cannot get help from an uncharitable person or money from someone who has none. Jerry and James spent two hours trying to convince the old miser to contribute to the children’s hospital; finally, James turned to Jerry and said in disgust, “This is hopeless. We can’t get blood from a stone.” _ The government can’t increase taxes any further—nobody has the money! You can’t get blood from a turnip.

Inf. No one can do better than that. (This you represents both personal and impersonal antecedents. That is, it means second person singular or plural, and anyone.) _ Mary: Wow! Look at the size of that lobster! It looks yummy! Bill: Yeah. You can’t beat that. I wonder what it’s going to cost.  “What a view! Nothing like it anywhere! You can’t top this!” said Jeff, admiring his room’s ocean view.

Inf. No one can do better than that. (This you represents both personal and impersonal antecedents. That is, it means second person singular or plural, and anyone.) _ Mary: Wow! Look at the size of that lobster! It looks yummy! Bill: Yeah. You can’t beat that. I wonder what it’s going to cost.  “What a view! Nothing like it anywhere! You can’t top this!” said Jeff, admiring his room’s ocean view.

dictionary.phrase: You can’t expect me to believe that.
dictionary.definition: That is so outrageous that no one could believe it.  Bill: My father is running for president. Bob: You can’t expect me to believe that.  Jane: Everyone in our family has one extra toe. Mary: You don’t expect me to believe that!

dictionary.phrase: You don’t expect me to believe that.
dictionary.definition: That is so outrageous that no one could believe it.  Bill: My father is running for president. Bob: You can’t expect me to believe that.  Jane: Everyone in our family has one extra toe. Mary: You don’t expect me to believe that!

Inf. a catch phrase said when someone, including the speaker, has lost in a contest or failed at something. (The you is impersonal, meaning one, anyone. The apostrophe on ’em is not always used.) _ Mary: Gee, I came in last again! Jane: Oh, well. You can’t win them all. “Can’t win ’em all,” muttered Alice as she left the boss’s office with nothing accomplished.

Inf. a catch phrase said when someone, including the speaker, has lost in a contest or failed at something. (The you is impersonal, meaning one, anyone. The apostrophe on ’em is not always used.) _ Mary: Gee, I came in last again! Jane: Oh, well. You can’t win them all. “Can’t win ’em all,” muttered Alice as she left the boss’s office with nothing accomplished.

an indication of disbelief that someone might do something.  Bill: I’m going to run away from home! Jane: You couldn’t! _ Bill: I get so mad at my brother, I could just strangle him. Tom: You couldn’t do that!

an indication of disbelief that someone might do something.  Bill: I’m going to run away from home! Jane: You couldn’t! _ Bill: I get so mad at my brother, I could just strangle him. Tom: You couldn’t do that!

dictionary.phrase: You got to do what you got to do.
dictionary.definition: One has to do whatever it is that one feels obliged to do.  I know I wouldn’t ever agree to that kind of thing, but you got to do what you got to do.

dictionary.phrase: A man’s gotta do what a man’s gotta do.
dictionary.definition: One has to do whatever it is that one feels obliged to do.  I know I wouldn’t ever agree to that kind of thing, but you got to do what you got to do.

Inf.Wait and see what will happen.; If you wait, you will see that what I predict will be true.  John: You’ll get what you deserve! Just you wait! Jane: Mind your own business.  Bill: Things will get better. You just wait and see! Sue: Sure, but when?

Inf.Wait and see what will happen.; If you wait, you will see that what I predict will be true.  John: You’ll get what you deserve! Just you wait! Jane: Mind your own business.  Bill: Things will get better. You just wait and see! Sue: Sure, but when?

dictionary.phrase: You scared the hell out of me.
dictionary.definition: You frightened me very badly. (Also with subjects other than second person. Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _He scared the hell out of all of us. She really scared the pants off of me.

dictionary.phrase: You scared the crap out of me.
dictionary.definition: You frightened me very badly. (Also with subjects other than second person. Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _He scared the hell out of all of us. She really scared the pants off of me.

dictionary.phrase: You scared the dickens out of me.
dictionary.definition: You frightened me very badly. (Also with subjects other than second person. Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _He scared the hell out of all of us. She really scared the pants off of me.

dictionary.phrase: You scared the devil out of me.
dictionary.definition: You frightened me very badly. (Also with subjects other than second person. Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _He scared the hell out of all of us. She really scared the pants off of me.

dictionary.phrase: You scared me out of my wits.
dictionary.definition: You frightened me very badly. (Also with subjects other than second person. Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _He scared the hell out of all of us. She really scared the pants off of me.

dictionary.phrase: You scared the pants off (of) me.
dictionary.definition: You frightened me very badly. (Also with subjects other than second person. Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _He scared the hell out of all of us. She really scared the pants off of me.

dictionary.phrase: You win some, you lose some.
dictionary.definition: Prov. Cliché You cannot always succeed. (You can say this when you have not succeeded, to show that you are not discouraged.) _ Jill: I was sorry to hear that you didn’t win your court case. Jane: Well, you win some, you lose some.  Bill: I thought it was terrible that you didn’t get a prize in the art contest. Bob: You win a few, you lose a few.

dictionary.phrase: You win a few, you lose a few.
dictionary.definition: Prov. Cliché You cannot always succeed. (You can say this when you have not succeeded, to show that you are not discouraged.) _ Jill: I was sorry to hear that you didn’t win your court case. Jane: Well, you win some, you lose some.  Bill: I thought it was terrible that you didn’t get a prize in the art contest. Bob: You win a few, you lose a few.

Inf. Don’t worry. You will become more comfortable with this situation soon.; You will catch the spirit of the situation soon.  Bill: I just can’t seem to do this right. Bob: You’ll get into it. Mary: How long does it take to learn to work this computer? Jane: Don’t fret. You’ll get onto it.

Inf. Don’t worry. You will become more comfortable with this situation soon.; You will catch the spirit of the situation soon.  Bill: I just can’t seem to do this right. Bob: You’ll get into it. Mary: How long does it take to learn to work this computer? Jane: Don’t fret. You’ll get onto it.

Inf. You must be crazy for saying or doing that! (Said to someone who has said or done something silly or stupid.) _ Andy: Go to the Amazon? You’re out of your mind! Jane: Maybe so, but doesn’t it sound like fun? _ Mary: Come on, Jane. Let’s go swimming in the river. Jane: Look at that filthy water. Swim in it? You’ve got to be out of your mind!

dictionary.phrase: You’ve got to be out of your mind!
dictionary.definition: Inf. You must be crazy for saying or doing that! (Said to someone who has said or done something silly or stupid.) _ Andy: Go to the Amazon? You’re out of your mind! Jane: Maybe so, but doesn’t it sound like fun? _ Mary: Come on, Jane. Let’s go swimming in the river. Jane: Look at that filthy water. Swim in it? You’ve got to be out of your mind!
Inf. Be quiet!; Close your mouth and be quiet! _ “I’ve heard enough. Zip your lip!” hollered the coach. Andy: All right, you guys. Shut up! Zip it up! Bob: Sorry. Andy: That’s better.
Inf. Be quiet!; Close your mouth and be quiet! _ “I’ve heard enough. Zip your lip!” hollered the coach. Andy: All right, you guys. Shut up! Zip it up! Bob: Sorry. Andy: That’s better.

1. Sl. drug intoxicated.  She’s too zonked to drive.  Jed was almost zounked out to unconsciousness. 2. Sl. exhausted; asleep.  She was totally zonked out by the time I got home.  I feel zounked. Good night.

1. Sl. drug intoxicated.  She’s too zonked to drive.  Jed was almost zounked out to unconsciousness. 2. Sl. exhausted; asleep.  She was totally zonked out by the time I got home.  I feel zounked. Good night.
to pay a casual visit to someone. Why don’t you come around to visit next week? _ Why don’t you come around for a visit? You are welcome any time.
to pay a casual visit to someone. Why don’t you come around to visit next week? _ Why don’t you come around for a visit? You are welcome any time.
[for something] to collapse on someone or something.  The walls crashed in around the burning house. The branches of the tree crashed down on the roof.  The old barn crashed down.
[for something] to collapse on someone or something.  The walls crashed in around the burning house. The branches of the tree crashed down on the roof.  The old barn crashed down.

dictionary.phrase: do a dump on someone or something
dictionary.definition: Sl. to criticize someone or something; to destroy someone or something.  There is no need to do a dump on me. I didn’t wreck your car.  The boss— mad as a wet hen—dumped all over me.

dictionary.phrase: dump all over someone or something
dictionary.definition: Sl. to criticize someone or something; to destroy someone or something.  There is no need to do a dump on me. I didn’t wreck your car.  The boss— mad as a wet hen—dumped all over me.
to hang by something very thin, such as a thread or a hair.  The tiniest part of the mobile hung by a thread, the rest are on plastic cords.
to hang by something very thin, such as a thread or a hair.  The tiniest part of the mobile hung by a thread, the rest are on plastic cords.

1. Fig. to keep one’s emotions inside oneself.  You really shouldn’t hold those feelings inside of you.  I have kept all this inside myself too long.  You shouldn’t hold in all that anger. 2. Lit. to hold in one’s stomach, gut, belly, etc. Hold your belly in so you don’t look like a blimp.  Hold in your stomach.

1. Fig. to keep one’s emotions inside oneself.  You really shouldn’t hold those feelings inside of you.  I have kept all this inside myself too long.  You shouldn’t hold in all that anger. 2. Lit. to hold in one’s stomach, gut, belly, etc. Hold your belly in so you don’t look like a blimp.  Hold in your stomach.
to keep one’s emotions inside oneself.  You really shouldn’t hold those feelings inside of you.  I have kept all this inside myself too long.  You shouldn’t hold in all that anger.
to keep one’s emotions inside oneself.  You really shouldn’t hold those feelings inside of you.  I have kept all this inside myself too long.  You shouldn’t hold in all that anger.

dictionary.phrase: look down one’s nose at someone or something
dictionary.definition: to view someone or something as lowly or unworthy.  She looked down at all the waiters and treated them badly.  They looked down on our humble food. Don’t look down your nose at my car just because it’s rusty and noisy.

dictionary.phrase: look down on someone or something
dictionary.definition: to view someone or something as lowly or unworthy.  She looked down at all the waiters and treated them badly.  They looked down on our humble food. Don’t look down your nose at my car just because it’s rusty and noisy.
to investigate something. I’ll have to look into that matter.  The police checked into her story.  Don’t worry about your problem. I’ll see into it.
to investigate something. I’ll have to look into that matter.  The police checked into her story.  Don’t worry about your problem. I’ll see into it.

dictionary.phrase: lose one’s hold on someone or something
dictionary.definition: to fail to keep one’s handhold on someone or something.  I lost my hold on the child, and she nearly slipped away.  She lost her grip on the bag of jewels and it fell overboard.

dictionary.phrase: lose one’s grip on someone or something
dictionary.definition: to fail to keep one’s handhold on someone or something.  I lost my hold on the child, and she nearly slipped away.  She lost her grip on the bag of jewels and it fell overboard.

1. Cliché very plain and simple. (*Also: as ~.) _ Although his face was as plain as day, his smile made him look interesting and friendly. Fred: I have a suspicion that Marcia is upset with me. Alan: A suspicion? Come on, Fred, that’s been plain as a pikestaff for quite some time! 2. Cliché clear and understandable. (*Also: as ~.) _ The lecture was as plain as day. No one had to ask questions. Jane: I don’t understand why Professor Potter has been so friendly this week. Alan: It’s plain as the nose on your face. He wants to be nominated for Professor of the Year.

1. Cliché very plain and simple. (*Also: as ~.) _ Although his face was as plain as day, his smile made him look interesting and friendly. Fred: I have a suspicion that Marcia is upset with me. Alan: A suspicion? Come on, Fred, that’s been plain as a pikestaff for quite some time! 2. Cliché clear and understandable. (*Also: as ~.) _ The lecture was as plain as day. No one had to ask questions. Jane: I don’t understand why Professor Potter has been so friendly this week. Alan: It’s plain as the nose on your face. He wants to be nominated for Professor of the Year.

to discourage doing something; to reduce enthusiasm for something. (Alludes to cooling passion with cold water.) _ When my father said I couldn’t have the car, he poured cold water on my plans. John threw cold water on the whole project by refusing to participate.

to discourage doing something; to reduce enthusiasm for something. (Alludes to cooling passion with cold water.) _ When my father said I couldn’t have the car, he poured cold water on my plans. John threw cold water on the whole project by refusing to participate.
to adjust a radio or television set to receive a broadcast of someone or something.  Let’s tune in on the late news.  I don’t want to tune in tonight.
to adjust a radio or television set to receive a broadcast of someone or something.  Let’s tune in on the late news.  I don’t want to tune in tonight.

dictionary.phrase: watch out for someone or something
dictionary.definition: 1. to be on guard for someone or something; to be on watch for the arrival or approach of someone or something. Watch out for someone wearing a white carnation.  Look out for John and his friends. They’ll be coming this way very soon. 2. Fig. to try to avoid a confrontation with someone or something.  Watch out! That car nearly hit you! _Look out for John. He’s looking for you, and he’s really mad.  Thanks. I’d better look out.

dictionary.phrase: look out for someone or something
dictionary.definition: 1. to be on guard for someone or something; to be on watch for the arrival or approach of someone or something. Watch out for someone wearing a white carnation.  Look out for John and his friends. They’ll be coming this way very soon. 2. Fig. to try to avoid a confrontation with someone or something.  Watch out! That car nearly hit you! _Look out for John. He’s looking for you, and he’s really mad.  Thanks. I’d better look out.

to work very hard and sweat very much. (In the way that a horse works up a lather.) _ Don’t work yourself up into a lather. We don’t need to finish this today.  I worked myself into a sweat getting this stuff ready.

to work very hard and sweat very much. (In the way that a horse works up a lather.) _ Don’t work yourself up into a lather. We don’t need to finish this today.  I worked myself into a sweat getting this stuff ready.
acknowledgement for having tried to do something, even if it was not successful. (*Typically: get ~; give someone ~.) _ The plan didn’t work, but I’ll give you an A for effort for trying.

dictionary.phrase: Abandon hope, all ye who enter here.
dictionary.definition: Prov. If you come in, be prepared for the worst. (Describes a hopeless situation or one somehow similar to hell. Often used jocularly. This is the English translation of the words on the gate of Hell in Dante’s Inferno.) _ This is our cafeteria. Abandon hope, all ye who enter here!
to yield to the comforts or delights of something.  The children abandoned themselves to the delights of the warm summer day.
to leave a sinking ship.  The captain ordered the crew and passengers to abandon ship.

dictionary.phrase: abandon someone or something to someone or something
dictionary.definition: to leave a person, living creature, or thing to the care of someone or something; to give up someone or something to someone or something. (Usually with the thought that the abandoned person or thing will not receive the best of care.) _ They had to abandon the dogs to the storm.
the basic facts or principles of something. I have never mastered the ABCs of car maintenance.

dictionary.phrase: abduct someone from someone or something
dictionary.definition: to take away or kidnap a person from someone or from a particular place, usually in secret.  The thugs abducted the child from her mother.
to help someone in some deed; to help someone do something illegal. Surely you do not expect me to abet you in this crime!
to follow the rules of something; to obey someone’s orders.  John felt that he had to abide by his father’s wishes.
to remain with someone; to stay with someone. (Old and stilted. Primarily heard in the church hymn Eventide.) _ You are welcome to abide with me for a while, young man.
to be able to manage or execute something. (Often negative. Able to can be replaced with can.) _ We thought he could handle the new account, but he is simply not able to cut it.

dictionary.phrase: able to do something with one’s eyes closed
dictionary.definition: able to do something very easily, even without having to think about it or look at it. (Always affirmative. Able to can be replaced with can.) _ It’s easy. I can do it with my eyes closed.

Inf. alive, even if just barely. (Usually jocular. Alludes to the use of a small mirror placed under the nose to tell if a person is breathing or not.  Look, I don’t need an athlete to do this job! Anybody able to fog a mirror will do fine!
able to attend an event.  I don’t think I’ll be able to make your party, but thanks for asking me.
to be able to accept ridicule goodnaturedly; to be able to be the object or butt of a joke willingly. Better not tease Ann. She can’t take a joke.
to be rich and abundant in something; to have plenty of something. (A bit formal.) _The entire area abounds in game and fish.
to be plentiful with particular persons, other living beings, or objects.  The world abounds with talented people who are too shy to develop their talents.
busy doing something. (*Typically: be ~; get ~; go ~.) _ Why are you still in the house? It’s time to be about your business.  Why are you just standing there? You’d better get busy doing something!
in the process of doing something. (*Typically: be ~; get ~.) _I’d better be about my yard work.
a reversal of attitude or action. (*Typically: do ~; have ~.) _ She did an about-face on her rule about not eating in the living room. Now we can do it if we want.
more than is required; greater than the required amount. (*Typically: be ~; go ~.) _ The English teacher helped students after school every day, even though it was beyond the call of duty.
higher or better than the average. Max’s grades are always above average.
[of someone] too mature or honorable to do something. I thought you were above doing something so thoughtless.
better than average or normal.  His work is above par, so he should get paid better.
not deserving of blame or criticism.  Some politicians behave as though they are above reproach.
at a higher rank than someone else; serving as someone’s supervisor.  Ron is above Ginney, but he treats her like an equal.
to be in a position that is higher than someone or something.  The plane is now directly above us.

[for one] to be honest enough that no one would suspect one; in a position where one could not be suspected. (This is a translation of words attributed to Julius Caesar, who divorced his wife, Pompeia, on the grounds of her possible involvement in a public scandal; Caesar stated, “Caesar’s wife must be above suspicion.”) (*Typically: be ~; keep oneself ~; remain ~.) _The general is a fine old man, completely above suspicion.
not subject to the law; immune to the law.  None of us is above the law. We have to obey all of them.
in the open; visible to the public; honest.  Don’t keep it a secret. Let’s make certain that everything is aboveboard.
keeping even with someone or something. (*Typically: be ~; get ~; keep ~; stay ~.) _ I had to run hard to stay abreast of Sally.
to steal or run away with someone or something; to make off with someone or something in secret.  The boys absconded with all the dessert.

dictionary.phrase: Absence makes the heart grow fonder.
dictionary.definition: Prov. You will like someone or something better if that person or thing is far away.  Ever since Carla’s boyfriend moved away, she can’t stop thinking about him. Absence makes the heart grow fonder.

dictionary.phrase: absent oneself from someone or something
dictionary.definition: to remain away from or avoid someone or some place.  Fred absented himself from the meeting, which he was certain would be boring.

absent from a military unit without permission; absent from anything without permission. (AWOL is an abbreviation. This is a serious offense in the military. *Typically: be ~; go ~.) _ The soldier was taken away by the military police because he was absent without leave.
a bumbling professor who overlooks everyday things.  Fred is such an absentminded professor. He’d forget his head if it wasn’t screwed on.

Prov. One who has total authority is very likely to abuse his position. (This phrase was used by the British historian Lord Acton: “Power tends to corrupt and absolute power corrupts absolutely.”) _We thought that Johnson would be a responsible mayor, but within a year of taking office, he was as bad as all the rest. Absolute power corrupts absolutely.
a strong denial or refusal. (Compare this with Definitely not!) _ Bob: Can I please have the car again tonight? Father: Absolutely not! You can’t have the car every night!

dictionary.phrase: absorb oneself in someone or something
dictionary.definition: [for someone] to become very interested or preoccupied with something or someone else’s interests. Tom would often absorb himself in his children’s activities on weekends.
[of a person or a group of people] to include someone in all the activities of the group; to integrate someone into something.  The club absorbed the new members into the organization.
[of matter or substance] to draw something into itself.  The sponge absorbed all the moisture into its fibers.
to soak up a fluid with something.  Henry absorbed the spilled milk with a sponge.
to avoid some activity or the use of some substance, such as alcohol, drugs, sex, or food.  They abstained from hard liquor and any other kind of intoxicants.
to choose not to vote either for or against a proposition or nominee. I will have to abstain from voting since I cannot make up my mind.

dictionary.phrase: abstract something from someone or something
dictionary.definition: to steal something from someone or something. (Formal.) _The officer was found guilty of abstracting a rather large amount of money from the company.
to take the important information from a longer document; to extract the essentials or the gist from a piece of complicated writing.  Can you abstract a shorter article from this material?
[particularly of the edge of an area of land] to meet or touch something along one boundary or at one point.  Our land abuts on the shopping center’s parking lot.
to rest firmly against something solid.  The end of the board abutted against the foundation.

1. to agree to the terms or demands that someone has stated.  We cannot accede to your demands. 2. to assume a position of power or authority; to begin serving in one’s official capacity.  She acceded to the office of mayor in January.
to consent to receive or consider someone as a particular type of person or a person who can serve a particular role.  Sally finally accepted herself as the only possible peacemaker in the dispute.

1. to agree that something will serve in payment of a debt or in return for something.  This receipt shows that we have accepted your money as payment on your debt.  This money has been accepted as reimbursement for the expenditure. 2. to resign [oneself] to something that cannot be changed.  I must accept what you say as the final decision.
permission to approach someone or something; the right to use someone or something. (*Typically: get ~; have ~; give someone ~.) _ Can you get access to a computer?
Inf. deliberate, but meant to look like an accident.  Then, I accidentally-on-purpose spilled water on him.

Prov. It is impossible to completely prevent things from going wrong. (Often used to console someone who has made a mistake or caused an accident.) _ Child: Mommy, I spilled grape juice all over the carpet! Mother: Don’t cry, honey. Accidents will happen.  Jill: I’m so embarrassed. I was just tapping on your window to wake you up. I didn’t mean to break it. Jane: Accidents will happen.
to adapt oneself to something, such as someone else’s needs or a new environment. Please try to accommodate yourself to our routine.
to provide something special for someone; to do something that provides for someone’s needs or desires.  We will try to accommodate you with an earlier f light.
with something extra to go along with something else; with something to complement something else. Dessert was accompanied by a fine white wine.

1. [for someone] to go with someone on a trip, journey, adventure, etc. Would you please accompany me on my next trip? 2. [for something] to be brought with someone on a trip, journey, etc.  My cameras always accompany me on my travels.

dictionary.phrase: accompany someone on a musical instrument
dictionary.definition: to provide complementary instrumental music for someone’s musical performance.  Sally accompanied the singer on the piano.
to use a particular musical instrument to play music that goes along with someone else’s musical performance.  She accompanied Mary with her f lute.
to agree with or match up with something; to jibe with something. Does this accord with what you heard?

according to the rules; in keeping with the way something is normally done. (Alludes to the rules for playing games. Edmond Hoyle wrote a widely used book with rules for card games. This expression is usually used for something other than games.) _ That’s wrong. According to Hoyle, this is the way to do it.
according to the way one believes; according to the way one’s conscience or inclinations lead one.  John may have been wrong, but he did what he did according to his own lights.
as said or indicated by someone or something.  According to the weather forecast, this should be a beautiful day.
in proportion to something.  You will get paid according to the number of hours that you work.
to know the state of or whereabouts of someone or something. (Usually in reference to some person or thing placed in one’s charge.) _ They cannot account for three of the passengers.
to explain something. Your explanation accounts for everything that has happened.
to assign or attribute a deed to someone; to assign or attribute praise to someone. (Often passive.) _We can accredit this great success to Fred and his committee.
[used of interest paid on money] to be credited to an account or to a person’s account.  Interest will accrue to your account as long as the account is active.
to charge someone with a crime, a violation of rules or instructions, or doing something wrong.  Please don’t accuse me of forgetting to lock the door.

dictionary.phrase: accustom someone to someone or something
dictionary.definition: to get someone used to someone or something.  I think we can accustom Fred to the new rules without difficulty.
to be lucky in getting admitted to something. I aced into the history class at the last minute.
to be fortunate or lucky.  Freddy aced out at the dentist’s office with only one cavity.
to get out of something through luck; to evade or avoid something narrowly.  I just aced out of having to take the math test!
to maneuver someone out; to win out over someone. Martha aced out Rebecca to win the first place trophy.

a weak point or fault in someone or something otherwise perfect or excellent. (From the legend of Greek hero Achilles, who had only one vulnerable part of his body, his heel; as an infant his mother had held him by one heel to dip him in the River Styx to make him invulnerable.) _He was very brave, but fear of spiders was his Achilles’ heel.
the feeling of pain because of love that is lost or has faded away. (Described as being in the heart, where love is said to reside.) _I try to tell my aching heart that I don’t love him.
a test whose findings are beyond doubt or dispute. The senator doesn’t look too popular just now, but the acid test will be if he gets reelected.
to agree or announce publicly that a person holds a particular office or station, or that a person has particular qualities.  She found it difficult to acknowledge herself as a failure.
to admit or state that someone is correct about something.  Bill said that the car was useless, and the mechanic acknowledged him to be right.
to agree or announce publicly that something is as previously stated.  The president acknowledged the statement as the truth.
to report receiving something, such as a package, letter, or notice. The company acknowledged receipt of the merchandise I returned.

to introduce someone to an unfamiliar thing; to become familiar with something; to get to know something; to tell someone the facts [about someone or something].  It took a month for the new attorney to acquaint herself with the facts in the case.

[of a person] known to someone; [of a person] having been introduced to someone. (*Typically: be ~; become ~; get ~.) _We are only acquainted with each other. We are certainly not what you would call close friends.
familiar with something; able to understand or recognize something. (*Typically: be ~; become ~; get ~.) _ Tom is fully acquainted with the way we do things.
to give in to someone or someone’s wishes; to agree, perhaps reluctantly, to someone’s ideas or requests. We are willing to acquiesce to your demands.
to establish someone’s innocence of a criminal charge or the blame for some wrongdoing.  The investigator acquitted Wally of the charges.
[distributed] equally for everyone or everything.  The school board raised the pay of all the teachers across the board.
to perform in the capacity of someone, temporarily or permanently; to serve in some special capacity, possibly temporarily.  This is Mr. Smith. He’ll act as manager from now on.

1. to represent someone in an official capacity; to represent the interests of someone.  Don’t worry. I am acting for the owner. I am his real estate agent. 2. to take action when the proper person fails to take action.  I had to act for her since she was out of town.
an act or deed demonstrating religious faith; an act or deed showing trust in someone or something.  For him to trust you with his safety was a real act of faith.

an occurrence or an event for which no human is responsible; an act of nature such as a storm, an earthquake, or a wildfire.  Will your insurance com- pany pay for damage caused by earthquakes and other acts of God?
an international act of warlike violence for which war is considered a suitable response.  To bomb a ship is an act of war.
to behave badly. (Usually used to describe young people.) _ Your son has been acting out in the classroom, and his teacher feels that professional intervention is desirable.

1. to perform in real life a role that one has imagined in a fantasy.  When I was onstage, I was really acting an old fantasy out.  I acted out an old fantasy onstage. 2. to convert one’s bad feelings into action rather than words. Don’t act your aggressions out on me! _She acted out her aggression. 3. to demonstrate or communicate something through gestures or action rather than words.  Act your request out, if you can’t say it.  She had a sore throat and had to act out her request.
[for a thing or a person] to behave badly. This car is acting up again.

1. to take action on a particular problem. (Upon is more formal and less commonly used than on.) _I will act on this immediately. 2. to take action because of some special information. The police refused to act upon his complaint because he was an ex-convict. 3. to perform on something, usually the stage (in a theater).  Ken has never acted on the stage or in front of a camera.

Behave more maturely! (A rebuke for someone who is acting childish. Often said to a child who is acting like an even younger child.) _ Child: Aw, come on! Let me see your book! Mary: Be quiet and act your age. Don’t be such a baby!
Prov. Cliché What you do is more significant than what you say.  You keep saying that you’ll do your fair share of the housework. Remember that actions speak louder than words.

dictionary.phrase: adapt someone or something to something
dictionary.definition: to cause someone or something to change, adjust to, or get used to something else.  Can’t you adapt yourself to my way of doing things?
to change or alter something for use with something else.  Has this furnace been adapted for natural gas?
to derive something from something else; to create by modifying something else.  I adapted my new musical from a novel.
to convert something to fit or work with something else. We converted our furnace to natural gas.
to adapt or get used to someone or something.  Please try to adapt to our routine.

Cliché to make a bad situation worse; to hurt the feelings of a person who has already been hurt. First, the basement f looded, and then, to add insult to injury, a pipe burst in the kitchen. My car barely started this morning, and to add insult to injury, I got a f lat tire in the driveway.
to increase the intensity or amount of something by giving more (of something) to it.  You added too much sugar to my coffee.
to sum or total two or more things.  Add these two together and tell me what you get.
to sum or total a set of figures.  Please add these figures up again.  I didn’t add up these figures!
[for a set of figures] to equal a total.  These figures don’t add up to the right total!

to cause someone to become habituated to something, usually alcohol or some another drug.  The hospital personnel were thought to have addicted John to morphine.  She ended up addicting herself to the substance.

dictionary.phrase: address comments or remarks to someone
dictionary.definition: to say something directly to a specific person or group of persons.  George addressed his remarks to everyone.
to speak directly to a particular person, rather than someone else. I did not address myself to you!
to turn one’s complete attention to something, such as a problem or an issue.  Please address yourself to these current, pressing problems.

dictionary.phrase: address someone as a specific title or attribute
dictionary.definition: 1. to talk to or write to a person, using a particular title.  They addressed Abraham Lincoln as “Mr. President.” 2. to treat a person you are talking with in a particular manner.  You should address him as your equal.
to write someone’s name and address on an envelope, package, letter, etc. Gilbert addressed the envelope to Walter.
to stick to something.  The stamp won’t adhere to the envelope.
to bring a meeting to a temporary close so the participants can take part in some other activity.  We must adjourn for the day.
to bring a meeting to a temporary close so the participants can move to another place (where the meeting will be started again). We adjourned to the sitting room.
to make changes in one’s opinion or attitude toward someone or something, such as a change in one’s life or environment. Can’t you adjust yourself to your new office?
to make something fit something else; to alter something to make it suitable for something else.  The builder adjusted the plans for the new house to the requirements of the fire marshal.

dictionary.phrase: administer something to someone or an animal
dictionary.definition: to present or apply something to a person or an animal.  The vet administered the drug to the cow.
to have a positive feeling toward someone because of something.  I really admire you for your courage.
Rur. to want to do something, to be happy to do something.  He asked her to the dance. She said she would admire to go with him.
to allow someone to enter some place.  They refused to admit us into the theater.
to allow something to be introduced into something else.  You cannot admit this document into the body of evidence!
to confess something to someone.  Harry admitted his error to his uncle.
to acknowledge or confess something; to acknowledge or confess to having done something.  Max would not admit to anything.
to warn or scold someone mildly for doing something. The nurse admonished the patient for not eating her dinner.
to choose someone as something.  The committee will adopt Jane as its candidate.
to take on something, such as a policy or principle, as one’s own.  I will adopt this policy as my own.
to be in awe of someone for doing something well. Everyone adores Sally for her wonderful sense of humor.
to be in awe of someone because of a particular trait or feature.  Robert adores Mary for her smiling eyes.

dictionary.phrase: adorn someone or something with something
dictionary.definition: to decorate or ornament someone or something with something. They adorned the room with garlands of f lowers.
to dilute or taint something with some other substance.  They adulterated the wine with some sort of drug.

dictionary.phrase: advance something to someone or something (against something)
dictionary.definition: to make an early payment of a sum of money promised or owed to a person or organization.  We advanced the money to Tom against his next month’s salary.
to move forward in the direction of someone or something.  The line of people slowly advanced to the door of the theater.

to move toward someone or something. (Typically in military maneuvers or in team sports, such as American football. Upon is more formal and less commonly used than on.) _ They advanced upon the town, firing their rif les and shouting.
to advertise one’s intention to purchase something or hire a particular type of person.  Did you advertise for a new receptionist?
to make known by public notice that something is to be sold at a particular price.  Is this the one that was advertised for a dollar?
to make known by public notice, such as broadcast or print notice, that something is available for purchase or rent.  Was this apartment advertised for rent?
to suggest that something not be done.  Lisa always advises against hasty actions.

dictionary.phrase: advise someone about someone or something
dictionary.definition: to inform someone about someone or something; to counsel someone about someone or something.  Bill needs to advise the committee about Karen’s request.
to encourage or counsel someone not to do something.  I advised Bill against quitting his job.
to inform someone of specific facts or some other information.  I hope you will advise Larry of the details of the proposal.

dictionary.phrase: advise someone on someone or something
dictionary.definition: to provide someone with specific advice about someone or something.  Would you please advise me on what kind of computer to buy?
a strong preference for something; a strong liking for something. Mary’s affinity for classical music accounts for her large collection of recordings.
to sign one’s name on something.  I affixed my signature to each of the documents.

dictionary.phrase: affix something to someone or something
dictionary.definition: to fasten or attach something to someone or something.  Please affix these tags to your luggage.
to burden someone with an annoying person. I was foolish enough to aff lict myself with my young cousin for the weekend.
